passages.text: We are now Underperform on both ANA and ANEA little over a year ago, we double- downgraded Acciona to Underperform in our Acciona, lacking Energia report, on the basis that underlying profitability and FCF were low. We reiterate this view, but now also downgrade subsidiary Acciona Energia to Underperform from Neutral, as we argue its assets are overvalued (or liabilities underestimated) and relative valuation looks too rich, with uncertainties on the growth profile. We are the only major broker with Underperform ratings on both names, with Street- low POs offering 25- 40% downside potential.

We can't see enough operational improvement to justify the companies' share price outperformance this year (Acciona shares \(60\% +\) ytd, Acciona Energia \(35\% +\) , compared to \(15\% +\) for the Utility sector). Indeed, we struggle to find evidence of meaningful improvements for renewable investments (see our Bloated Al- ppetite report) and FCF generation is still limited for the Infrastructure business. We note short interest has been volatile, with technical factors likely more responsible (equity swaps at both) than fundamentals, which should start to matter more in the medium term.

Pure utilities have outperformed the sector by 20pp+ on average since US tariffs were announced, and Acciona Energia has outperformed by 35pp+. WE think the shares now look quite expensive at 10x 2y forward EBITDA, compared to utilities or clean energy names at 8x. While we still think consensus might not fully account for growth (and capital gains), we believe the shares have already moved ahead of revisions (and are expensive). We downgrade to Underperform with a Street- low PO of 17.5 (see detail on estimate changes inside).

One bull argument for Acciona is the depressed implied valuation for the Infrastructure stub (we estimate negative - 1.4bn). However, it is also now at the highest of the last four years, despite still low FCF generation (we estimate 50m on average 2025- 27E) and a lack of catalysts for any discount to unwind. Multiples for the group look too rich, in our view, trading like a pure play renewable on 21x 2y P/E (compared EDPR on 22x, construction and concessions on 13x) despite \(>\) Employed by a non- US affiliate of BofAS and is not registered/qualified as a research analyst under the FINRA rules. Lacking Energia: Act IIA little over a year ago, we double- downgraded Acciona to Underperform in our Acciona, lacking Energia report on the basis that underlying profitability and FCF were low. We reiterate this view, but now also downgrade subsidiary Acciona Energia to Underperform. We argue that its assets are overvalued (or liabilities underestimated) and that relative valuation looks too rich, with uncertainties on the growth profile. We think the companies' outperformance this year (Acciona shares \(60\% +\) ytd, Acciona Energia \(- 30\%\) compared to \(- 20\%\) for the Utility sector) has little to do with fundamental improvements. Indeed, we struggle to find evidence of such improvements across the renewable sector (see our Bloated Al- ppetite report) and FCF generation is still limited for the construction and infrastructure businesses. We are the only major broker with Underperform ratings on both names, with Street- low POs and significant \(20\% +\) downside potential for both.

Downgrade Acciona Energia to U/PPure utilities have outperformed the sector by a median \(+27\) pp since the US tariffs were announced, with Acciona Energia shares outperforming by \(+34\) pp. However, we think the shares now look quite expensive at \(10x\) 2y forward EBITDA (and \(11.5x\) excluding capital gains) compared to the sector or clean energy names on \(8x\) . While we still think consensus might not fully account for growth (and/or capital gains), we believe the shares have already moved ahead of potential revisions (and are expensive). The recent outperformance should therefore unwind as execution and leverage headroom remains tight on a dual pipeline of gross additions and asset rotations. A take- out by parent Acciona remains an upside risk (management continue to evaluate all options), but we think this is unlikely, with the shares now closer to the 2021 IPQ price of €26.7.

Shares for our coverage of European pure- play renewables have returned a median \(+23\%\) since the beginning of the year, strong performance compared to \(- 32\%\) in 2024 and \(- 6\%\) median on average across 2021, 2022 and 2023.

Whilst recent performance can largely be ascribed to changes in US policy, we highlight Acciona Energia's particular outperformance, with shares returning \(+37\%\) this year and \(+41\%\) since US tariffs were announced, compared to a \(+23\%\) and \(+33\%\) median, respectively, for our pure- play coverage, and \(+22\%\) and \(+7\%\) for the wider utility sector (see Exhibit 2). We ascribe this outperformance to (1) mean- reversion, with shares underperforming our pure- play coverage ahead of US tariffs; but also (2) progress on disposals, with 136MW of wind assets in Peru announced on 25 June, and 440MW of
wind assets in Spain announced on 28 July. However, we think shares have now run ahead of fundamentals and look too expensive.
Source: BofA Global Research, Bloomberg Note: European renewables as market-cap weighted average of Acciona Energia, EDPR, ERG, Grenergy, Orsted, Solaria as of 1 Jan 2024. BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Looking at valuation across the last 10 years, renewables (and wider clean energy transition) multiples have largely corrected since the enthusiasm of the 2020- 23 years, when ESG investment trends pushed them to much higher levels. ESG investments are now de- emphasized (Morningstar reported record- high outflows of global ESG funds in Q1 2025, with the \(10^{\text{th}}\) consecutive quarter of outflows in the US and Europe's first net outflow since 20181).

Rates have also affected multiples. US 10y yields currently stand above \(4\%\) , compared to \(1.5 - 3\%\) in 2015- 19 (they were down to \(0.5\%\) in 2020 before coming back to \(4\%\) in 2023), but they have equally affected the wider Utility sector.

EV/EBITDA 2y forward multiples now stand at 9x for our renewables coverage (see Exhibit 3) compared to 8x for the Utility sector and 8x for clean energy transition names and against 9x, 7x and 7.5x, respectively, across 2015- 19 (and 12.5x, 8x and 11.5x during 2020- 23). Whilst this looks more reasonable to us compared to history, our coverage premium has started to gap up, but we struggle to find evidence of material fundamental improvements across the renewable sector (see our Bloated Al- ppetite report).

Exhibit 3: Sentiment has improved but we caution against too much excitement like in 2020-23 European renewables vs Utility sector and Clean Energy Transition index 2y forward EV/EBITDA, Aug 15 - Aug 25
Source: Bloomberg consensus Note: European renewables as the median of Acciona Energia, EDPR, ERG, Grenergy, Orsted, Solaria.

Clean energy transition names and utilities are \(+7\%\) more expensive on \(+0.7pp\) better growth CAGR on average, lagging overall equities at \(+18\%\) more expensive for \(- 0.4pp\) less growth CAGR. We reiterate our view on the utility sector's relative cheapness in our Themes, ideas and feedback: sector momentum has turned strategy update of March 2025. While it is not our role to comment on the relative cheapness (or otherwise) of the clean energy transition index (or wider equities), one could argue that our European renewables coverage looks attractive (much stronger growth at lower multiples).

However, this is skewed by smaller names (Grenergy with \(>30\%\) EBITDA growth in the next two years and Solaria with \(>10\%\) ) and when looking at individual relative valuations, we find Acciona Energia (and EDPR) to be expensive compared to history and, more importantly, to the sector or clean energy transition names today.

Exhibit 4: Clean energy and utilities are slightly more expensive today at 8x vs 7.5x for +60bps better growth, lagging overall equities (20% more expensive for - 40bps lower growth)Utility sector, Clean Energy Transition, and equity index 2y forward EV/EBITDA and CAGR (Bloomberg consensus)
Source: Bloomberg consensus Note: We use 2025-27 CAGR for our coverage and indexes, except 2024-26 for SXXP (data errors). BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

We use the below screen (see Exhibit 6) to plot our coverage based on our EV adjustments (meaning multiples are more expensive compared to Bloomberg's EV bridge) and forecasts (higher than consensus as we fully model pipeline growth). We further plot valuation at our PO. We argue that Acciona Energia (and EDPR) look expensive relative to its peers. Bottom- line, this screen is one of several tools we use to inform our ratings.

We use the below screen (see Exhibit 7) to plot our own estimate of net operational assets and pipeline values (blue bars) as a share of our PO (rebased to 100 at the red dotted line) and against current share price (red dots). Taking Acciona Energia, our PO is mostly composed of operational assets (big dark blue bar) and suggests that the market overestimates said operational value and/or pipeline valuation and/or underestimates liabilities (where we believe we have a more conservative and granular view than consensus, not limiting our scope to net financial debt). This supports our Underperform rating on Acciona Energia (and even more so on EDPR). Bottom-line, this screen is one of several tools we use to inform our ratings.
BofA renewables pure-players BofA SOTP valuation mix vs current share price (as % PO)
**Source**: BofA Global Research estimatesNote: Greenergy operational value is negative from high capex and debt phasing in the Atacama project

One source of conflict in our ratings has to do with consensus forecasts for Acciona Energia and EDPR. Indeed, we have Underperform ratings on both despite our EBITDA forecasts being \(+9\%\) above across 2026E and 2027E.

However, we caution against reading too much into consensus forecasts given the lack of granularity on underlying asset growth and accounting for capital gains. Our conversations with investors tell us that the sell- side is using a very wide range of assumptions (low to high gross capacity, including or not including asset rotations, including or not including capital gains) and that revisions could be skewed by large modelling assumption changes, especially as we move closer to the forecasted year.

Indeed, whilst our forecasts are \(6\%\) above consensus on average for Acciona Energia and EDPR for 2026E and \(10\%\) for 2027E, they are \(- 5\%\) and \(+1\%\) , respectively, on average excluding capital gains (see Exhibit 8). This, despite net capacity additions \(- 24\%\) lower on average across 2026- 27E for Acciona Energia, and \(+35\%\) for EDPR (see Exhibit 9).

Note, however, a more restricted sample of estimates on capacity additions (5 for Acciona Energia, 8 for EDPR compared to 7 and 17, respectively, at the EBITDA level on Visible Alpha), which makes readings between the two estimates quite difficult.
Exhibit 8: Our estimates are \(+9\%\) above consensus on average over 2026-27E but are \(-2\%\) below ex capital gains... Acciona Energia and EDPR EBITDA forecasts (€m) vs BBG
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg, Visible Alpha
Exhibit 9: We have different asset growth assumptions (24% over 2026-27E for ANE, \(+35\%\) for EDPR) and thus capital gain pool Acciona Energia and EDPR net capacity additions forecasts (MW) vs VA
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Visible Alpha

With this in mind, we find it difficult to draw strong conclusions against consensus - but we still argue that our forecasts on Acciona Energia are higher because of asset rotations (higher EBITDA forecasts from capital gains commensurate with lower net additions forecasts from higher asset rotations).

Looking at consensus revisions over the last 12 months, it looks to us as if consensus has started to include capital gains for 2025 only (strong revisions given significant \(\) 400m+\(capital gains from the hydro sale) but not beyond (lower estimates from potentially lower growth, but also potentially not assuming or modelling further asset rotations - see Exhibit 10).

We also note that short interest has come down (see Exhibit 11) from \(18\%\) to \(14\%\) with the recent hike from \(10\%\) six months ago, which might have more to do with technical factors (counterparties to the three successive €100m equity swaps done by Acciona for a total of \(- 4.6\%\) of share capital).
Exhibit 10: We do not think the perimeter is comparable to consensus Acciona Energia consensus EBITDA revisions vs BofA (Em) Aug 24 - Aug 25
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg
Exhibit 11: Short interest has come down Acciona Energia short interest (% free float) Aug 22 - Aug 25
Source: BofA Global Research

While we are cognizant that higher forecasts should theoretically support share price performance (a risk to our Underperform ratings), we think this has already been reflected in recent share price performance, alongside the general improvement in sentiment for renewables. We also think the gap between the two should compress overall valuation, with higher numbers but much lower multiples.

Exhibit 12: EDPR shares have declined from €18 to €7 alongside earnings from €3.2bn to €2.1bn but have recovered to €10 despite stale earnings... EDPR EBITDA 2027 forecasts (Em) against share price, Sept '23 to Aug '25

Exhibit 13: ...as have ANE shares declined from €28 to €15 alongside earnings from €1.6bn to €1.25bn but have recovered to €24 despite stale earnings... ANE EBITDA 2027 forecasts (Em) against share price, Sept '23 to Aug '25

Leverage in pure play renewables doubled from 2x on average in 2022 to 4x in 2024 (see Exhibit 15). We expect a significant drop in net capacity growth in the coming years, as gross ambitions have been revised down, while asset rotation programs have been maintained or raised, meaning leverage should step down to 3x by 2027E as net capacity
growth slows. Across the board, we expect net capacity growth for the sector to fall from \(13\%\) on average in the last five years to \(5.5\%\) in the next three years (see Exhibit 14).

For Acciona Energia, we expect growth to pick back up towards \(5\%\) in 2026 (with 2025 impacted by the hydro sale and new asset rotation program), with leverage down from \(3.6x\) in 2024 toward \(2.7x\) in 2027E. However, this leverage reduction (and commensurate growth trajectory) is not without risks (execution risks on two pipelines of gross additions + asset rotations). We also flag that economic leverage is much higher than reported leverage (see below section on underlying leverage), meaning a tight execution window overall.
Exhibit 14: Renewable pure players have lowered their ambitions Net GW capacity growth in renewables \((\%)\) 2020-27E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report
Exhibit 15: Leverage has doubled, but is now coming down Net debt including leases/reported EBITDA excluding capital gains 2022-27E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report

Renewable developers can operate two levers to control leverage. They can either build fewer assets (lower gross additions) or sell more (higher asset rotations) or a combination thereof. This commensurately impacts the growth trajectory. Over the last few years, gross addition (and thus growth) ambitions have been revised down across the sector, and equally so for Acciona Energia.

Near the time of its 2021 IPO, Acciona Energia targeted slightly less than 2GW of gross additions in 2025, without depending on farm- downs/asset rotation for funding. However, it now expects 0.6GW of gross additions for 2025 and is completing a €3bn asset rotation program over 2024- 25, meaning assets are declining on a net basis for 2025 (see Exhibit 16). Management specifically mentioned that the growth cut was largely due to deleveraging and credit rating protection for Acciona Energia, which issues debt direct (contrariwise to EDPR, which raises debt at the parent EDPR level).
Exhibit 16: Acciona Energia strategy now relies heavily on asset rotations to fund growth Acciona Energia targeted medium-term capacity additions (GW) per annum
Source: Company report

We think this deleveraging (and growth- funding) strategy is not without risks. Acciona Energia now has execution risks over two pipelines (gross additions and asset rotations), similarly to EDPR. Any misstep or phasing could impact leverage ratios, as well as net debt from spending or proceeds, along with reported EBITDA, which benefits from asset rotation gains. Whilst asset rotations are a standard strategy across the sector (we highlight, however, that ERG does not have an asset rotation program, and more limited gross additions) there is evidence to suggest some caution (and/or warrant some growth and pipeline discount for execution risks) in recent times.

Acciona Energia's initial 2024 wind sale was delayed into summer 2025, and sold crown- jewel hydro assets instead to progress on asset rotations. The company also paused on 0.4GW of storage investments in the US, given volatility in market conditions (40% of 2025 targeted additions). Whilst the company continues to execute and should complete the current €3bn asset rotation program over 2024- 25, and whilst we acknowledge exceptional conditions or changes in market conditions in recent years, we still argue that the company has not yet proven that it can steadily execute on both gross additions, and even more so on asset rotations.
Exhibit 17: Asset rotations are a big part of ANE, EDPR pipeline... Net GW capacity growth ex asset rotations as % of gross (MW)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates
Exhibit 18: ... meaning also a big part of EBITDA Reported EBITDA and capital gains as % of total (€m)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates

Indeed, we have repeatedly argued that underlying leverage for renewable developers was and remains much higher than headline figures suggest. We still believe net debt is understated, notably given capex payables and tax equity liabilities in the US, while EBITDA benefits from tax credits and asset rotations. We do agree that there are some unfavourable factors as well, as operating assets do not contribute for the entire year (with a CoD likely towards year- end). We could, however, also question if capex is fully paid, given high property, plant and equipment payables and therefore capex being financed by working capital rather than debt. Across our coverage, we estimate economic leverage 1- 3x higher than reported (see Exhibit 19).

Looking at 2025, we estimate that Acciona Energia's economic leverage will be more than twice reported figures, given exceptional one- off gains from the hydro sale. In the context of the sector, we find this relatively unappealing given it remains stubbornly higher, but acknowledge it is not as unappealing as EDPR (see Exhibit 20).

We also note that major debt items we consider (capex payables and tax equity liabilities) have almost doubled from €700m in 2021 to €1.3bn in 2024 (adding 1.3x turn to our economic leverage in 2024). We acknowledge they did increase by €230m only over the two last years, as capacity additions peaked; however, the company should be facing cash- flow drags in the coming years as capacity additions reduce (capex working capital outflows, assuming similar financing schedule) and tax equity investors are returned their investments.

Assuming no capacity additions, Acciona Energia would face payments on €770m of accrued capex, whilst assuming \(15\%\) tax equity cash outflow per annum (similar to EDPR over the last five years) would mean €80m cash flow drags for the next eight years. This would significantly use the - €800m of underlying cash flow from operations (2023- 24 average).
Exhibit 19: Underlying leverage 1-3x higher than reported IFRS leverage vs BofA economic adjustments (x)

Source: BofA Global Research estimates Note: Net debt including leases/reported EBITDA including capital gains Note: Economic liabilities including mainly tax equity, PPE payables, provisions BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

We have cut our EBITDA forecasts by - 5% on average to 2030E with slightly lower achieved prices and pipeline phasing, but with no change over 2025E. Our net debt estimate is slightly lower as we correct for a €300m flow in asset rotations, offsetting the lower valuation for operational assets (and with better medium- term pipeline value).
Exhibit 21: We cut our EBITDA on lower prices and pipeline phasing Changes in Acciona Energia estimates (Em, %)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates

We have made no changes to our valuation methodology. We continue to use a 8x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs 8.5x Y+1 median last two years). This values Acciona Energia slightly below other clean transition names on a forward- looking basis (SPGTCED index trading on 8.7x 2026) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables, as well as caution on gross deployments and asset rotations more specifically for Acciona Energia (our multiple implies 9.2x excluding capital gains).

We keep Underperform on AccionaWe think Acciona Energia is trading expensively and find reasons for Acciona Infrastructure's valuation to remain depressed, given low FCF generation. We do not see enough operational improvement to support the \(60\% +\) rally this year. This underpins our view that multiples for the group are too rich. We reiterate our Underperform rating on Acciona with \(- 40\%\) downside potential and a Street- low PO of €105.

Acciona's recent outperformance in contextAcciona shares have returned more than \(60\%\) this year, outperforming the utility, construction and industrial sectors by more than 45pp and supported by subsidiaries Acciona Energia and Nordex up \(35\%\) and \(90\%\) , respectively (see Exhibit 24). This means close to €4bn of capitalisation has been added over the period, of which €1.8bn is from Acciona Energia (economically owned over \(90\%\) including derivatives) and €1.1bn from Nordex (owned at \(47.1\%\) ) – and implies the 'stub' infrastructure business has also re- rated, or that the potential conglomerate discount has reduced. Technical factors are also likely at play – with two €100m equity swaps announced by the company in May and June of this year.

Exhibit 24: Acciona has strongly outperformed its main sectors this year Acciona, Acciona Energia, Nordex vs European Utility, Construction and Industrial sectors performance \((100 =\) 1 Jan 2024) Aug 23 to May 25

Despite the recent share performance, markets seem to ascribe a negative - €1.4bn equity value to Acciona's Infrastructure 'stub' business, once taking off the equity value of listed subsidiaries (Acciona Energia, economically owned more than \(90\%\) including derivatives, and Nordex, owned at \(47.1\%\) ) and the reported value of real estate assets (€1.9bn as of 1H25) and assuming other businesses at marginal equity value (biggest asset left is Bestinver, an asset management business with close to €7bn under management generating around €50m of EBITDA – see Exhibit 25).

This seem counterintuitive to us, as infrastructure is one of the thematic megatrends that investors have increasingly invested in, with the company itself posting record backlog levels and improving profitability over the last few quarters.
Exhibit 25: Markets seem to value the Acciona Infra 'stub' at a negative -1.4bn Acciona implied 'stub' equity values

However, markets have historically heavily discounted Acciona Infra's 'stub' business, with an average implied equity value of - €3bn over the last four years (since the Acciona Energia June 2021 IPO, assuming a similar methodology as previous – see Exhibit 26). We also note that conglomerate companies can trade well below the sum of their parts, at much deeper discounts than integrated companies, and thus the negative equity value implied on Acciona Infra's 'stub' business also reflects the wider group conglomerate discount.
Exhibit 26: Markets have historically heavily discounted Acciona Infra 'stub' Acciona implied 'stub' equity values, Jun 21 to Aug 25
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report, Bloomberg

Acciona's backlog stood at €29.4bn as of 1H25, up +3% since December 2024 (see Exhibit 27) and covers more than 3.5x 2024 revenues. We model underlying Construction growth of 3- 5% in 2025- 26 and commensurate Infrastructure EBIT growth of 3% (assuming around €70m in one- offs in 2024, as per company commentary – see Exhibit 28).

While management remains confident on risk returns for construction contracts, we think further margin expansion will be hard to achieve, as 77% of all contracts already have protection clauses (and as profitability has already improved over the last three years). We note that Australia (Acciona's largest market) has seen collaborative contracts' share grow only from 55% at end- 2023 to 60% in 1H25.
Exhibit 27: Acciona's backlog has grown 34% since 2022 Acciona Infrastructure backlog (€m) 2022-1H25
Source: Company reports
Exhibit 28: We expect 3% underlying EBIT growth Acciona Infrastructure EBIT and margin forecasts (€m, %) 2022-26E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report

We briefly look at Acciona Infrastructure's EBIT performance against selected peers, using ACS and Vinci in our European coverage for the global scale in construction, and Worley in our APAC colleagues' coverage given Acciona's large exposure in Australia.

We find Acciona's margin performance somewhat lacking at \(3 - 3.5\%\) against \(5\%\) on average for these selected peers over 2024- 26E (see Exhibit 29). While it is not the purpose of this note to go into detail on the differences between the groups, we still note that Acciona is already trading at P/E multiples much richer than these peers, (see Exhibit 30) despite lower margins, and much closer to pure- play renewables (with limited net income given high depreciation from rapid asset roll- out). This, in isolation, adds support for our Underperform rating.
Exhibit 29: Acciona's EBIT margins are lower than peers' Acciona Infrastructure EBIT margins against selected peers (%)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report
Exhibit 30: ... but P/E multiples are aligned Acciona and selected peers 2y forward P/E (consensus)
Source: Bloomberg Note: EDPR P/E off chart over the last 5-10Y between 25-35x

Similarly, our FCF analysis of Acciona's Infrastructure business shows that it generated only around €50m on average in 2022- 24 (starting from Group FCF and excluding Energia, Nordex, other activities, as well as adjusting for M&A and working capital - see
Exhibit 31) As a sense-check, we also estimate net income at the 'stub' level of €65m on average across these same years.

Whilst underlying FCF generation has improved recently, it will suffer from the equity contribution required by Acciona's portfolio of concessions (capex €100m higher in 2025, then again in 2027 as most concessions are under construction - see Exhibit 32),which will offset top-line growth and recent margin expansion.

**Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report**
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
**Exhibit 32: Acciona concessions are mostly under construction %**Acciona concession assets' status (as share of total capex)

We make limited underlying changes for Acciona, with our Infrastructure EBITDA forecasts unchanged over 2025-26E (and increased +2% in 2027E only as we plug in generic inflation). We also refresh for the subsidiaries, with group EBITDA unchanged in 2025E and cut -2% in 2026-27E (Acciona Energia down >5% but Nordex up >3%). Our net debt estimate is lower as we correct for a €300m flow in asset rotations in 2025.Our EPS estimate increases 15%+ in 2025E from lower net debt and thus lower interest charges, as well as a €86m provision reversal from Nordex. Our EPS estimates are marginally changed over 2026-27E.

Our EBITDA forecasts are >7% ahead of consensus over 2025-27, but we think the perimeter at Acciona Energia (with much more capital gains and asset growth in our forecasts compared to consensus, though granularity on accounting is relatively poor) is blurring the picture, meaning the comparison becomes increasingly difficult should we look at our forecasts excluding Acciona Energia and Nordex against consensus.

We slightly amend our valuation methodology.

For our SOTP, we continue to use DCFs for Acciona Energia. We also align our Infrastructure valuation what that of BofA peers, and now use 10x 2025E EBIT (which is identical to the methodology used by BofA for Vinci Contracting, Hochtief, and Worley) compared to 8x 2026E and \(8\%\) FCF 2026E. In addition, we now use no discount on real estate assets (compared to a \(10\%\) discount before). We update for the latest BofA valuation of Nordex. Our fair value improves thanks to Infrastructure and Nordex, as well as lower net debt. We keep our conglomerate discount at \(15\%\) .

For our P/E valuation, we keep 10x 2026E compared to a 14x median over the last two years, and 13.5x for ACS, Vinci and Worley - mostly as Acciona earnings are now distorted by volatile capital gains at Acciona Energia. Our implied multiple would be 13.5x excluding these capital gains. Our fair value is broadly unchanged.

Acciona EnergiaAcciona Energia continues to face an uncertain policy outlook and power market backdrop for renewables, with investors unwilling to pay for growth. The recent rally has little to do with organic improvement, despite some progress on asset rotations, as the growth ramp- up is uncertain and the track record on M&A is not fully established. A take- out by parent Acciona remains upside risk, but we do not think it likely.

Our PO for Acciona is derived from an equally- weighted average of a SOTP (with a mix of DCFs, EV/EBIT and FCF yield) and a group P/E multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for a renewables and construction conglomerate. Our resulting PO is 105.

For our SOTP, we feed in our Acciona Energia valuation based on existing assets and pipeline DCFs, with Acciona Infrastructure at 10x EBIT 2025. We add Nordex at BofA \(\epsilon 20+\) valuation, and Real Estate assets at 2025 gross asset value. We further apply a - \(15\%\) conglomerate discount.

For our P/E, we use a 10x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs 14x Y+1 median last 2 years) given our estimates now including capital gains in Acciona Energia's pipeline (excluding at c13.5x Y+1 P/E in- line with other construction conglomerates).

Our PO for Acciona Energia is derived from an equally- weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is 17.5.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(7 - 8\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and medium- term asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(50\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).

For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 8x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs 8.5x Y+1 median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables as well as caution on gross deployments and asset rotations more specifically for Acciona Energia.

Upside/downside to our PO are: wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

Our PO for EDPR is derived from an equally weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is €7.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(6 - 6.5\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(30\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).
For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 10x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs 8.2x Y+1 median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables.

Upside/downside to our PO are wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.
